data.title: 25 Songs Everyone Was Listening to in 1999
data.meta_description: From TLC's âNo Scrubsâ to Limp Bizkit's âNookie,â 1999 was both a good year for pop music and a weird one.
data.text:
In 1999, the final year of the 20th century, America was at a crossroads. While the nation was still enjoying the unprecedented peace and prosperity of the late â90s, anxiety related to the dreaded Y2K bug had many people fearing armageddon was imminent. Nobody could tell if it was the best of times or the end of timesâwhich might explain why sugary teen-pop and angry nu-metal were two of the biggest sounds around.

But thatâs not all people were rocking out to as the millennium approached. What follows is a list of 25 songs turning 25 in 2024. Itâs a testament to the wonderful weirdness of 1999, the year that gave us indelible hits by Limp Bizkit, Christina Aguilera, Macy Gray, and of course, Lou Bega.

1. Blondie // âMariaâ

Blondieâs first single since 1982 was a real doozy. In the UK, where the New York City rockers had always been huge, the song reached No. 1, making Blondie the first and only American act to top that countryâs charts in the â70s, â80s, and â90s. âMariaâ also made Blondie singer Debbie Harry, then 53, the oldest woman to have a No. 1 UK hit. (Cher had been slightly younger when she reached the summit with âBelieveâ the previous year.)

2. TLC // âNo Scrubsâ

âNo Scrubsâ gave TLC their third No. 1 hit on the Billboard Hot 100âand the songâs lyrics, all about broke dudes catcalling women from passing cars, put some men on the defensive. The New York City rap group Sporty Thievz even scored a Top 20 smash with their answer record, âNo Pigeons.â

3. Eminem // âMy Name Isâ

Produced by Dr. Dre, Eminemâs tongue-in-cheek breakthrough single, âMy Name Is,â samples British singer-songwriter Labi Siffreâs 1975 tune âI Got The â¦â Siffre refused to clear the sample until Eminem agreed to cut some of the songâs homophobic lyrics.

4. Britney Spears // â... Baby One More Timeâ

Although it was technically released in late 1998, Britney Spearsâs world-beating debut single, â... Baby One More Time,â remained massive throughout the following year. It topped the Billboard Hot 100 in January of â99, and Billboard later ranked it the fifth biggest song of the year. And to think, songwriter Max Martin originally intended the tune for TLC.

5. Tom Waits // âHold Onâ

Despite his craggy voice and penchant for bizarre storytelling, Tom Waits can make beautiful songs when he wants to. His acclaimed 1999 album Mule Variations includes âHold On,â an optimistic song of romantic resilience written with his wife, Kathleen Brennan. âHold Onâ earned Waits a Grammy nomination for Best Male Rock Vocal Performance. He lost to Lenny Kravitz.

6. Ricky Martin // âLivinâ La Vida Locaâ

The chart-topping breakthrough single for Puerto Rican heartthrob and former Menudo member Ricky Martin, which was completely inescapable in the summer of 1999, holds the distinction of being the first U.S. No. 1 hit recorded entirely with the digital audio workstation Pro Tools. That said, âLivinâ La Vida Locaâ does feature some real instruments, including horns and acoustic guitar.

7. Shania Twain // âMan! I Feel Like a Woman!â

Shania Twainâs gargantuan third album, Come On Over, dropped in 1997, but it kept spinning off singles into the new millennium. The most enduring of these may be âMan! I Feel Like a Woman!â, a strutting country-rock female-empowerment jam with a chorus thatâs meant to be screamed at the top of your lungs.

8. Blink-182 // âWhatâs My Age Again?â

Originally titled âPeter Pan Complex,â the gleefully immature breakout single for San Diego punk-rock goofballs blink-182 was born from a mistake. Bassist Mark Hoppus was trying to play Green Dayâs âJ.A.R.â on guitar, and he accidentally came up with the now-familiar intro riff to âWhatâs My Age Again?â

9. Jennifer Lopez // âIf You Had My Loveâ

J. Lo came strong out of the gate with her debut single, âIf You Had My Love,â which spent five weeks atop the Billboard Hot 100. Shortly before the song dropped, Michael Jackson heard producer Rodney Jerkinsâs demo and nearly opted to record it himself. Fortunately for Lopez, the King of Pop thought it would sound better with a female singer.Â

10. Ja Rule // âHolla Hollaâ

In the early 2000s, Ja Rule became a pop-rap titan with radio-ready jams like âLivinâ It Upâ and âAlways on Time.â But the NYC rapper actually came on the scene with 1999âs âHolla Holla,â a last-minute addition to his debut album, Venni Vetti Vecci. Def Jam had been asking for a hit single, and Ja delivered, cracking the Top 40 and setting the stage for future triumphs.

11. Smash Mouth // âAll Starâ

With âAll Star,â Smash Mouth avoided the curse of being a one-hit wonder (let us not forget 1997âs âWalkinâ On the Sunâ) and gave the world a perennial sports anthem, which is funny, since it was written by guitarist Greg Camp, the only member of Smash Mouth not into sports. Smash Mouth even performed âAll Starâ at the 1999 Home Run Derby at Fenway Park.

12. Red Hot Chili Peppers // âScar Tissueâ

The lead single from the seventh Red Hot Chili Peppers album features music by guitarist John Fruscianteâhis first after coming back in the fold after a six-year absence. Upon hearing the guitar riff, lead singer Anthony Kiedis immediately connected with the âplayful, happy-to-be-alive, phoenix-rising-from-the-ashes vibeâ and penned lyrics to match. The song became the groupâs first Top 10 pop hit since 1991.Â Â

13. Lit // âMy Own Worst Enemyâ

Lit frontman A. Jay Popoff told SPIN magazine that he sang âMy Own Worst Enemy,â his bandâs punky, poppy 1999 breakthrough smash, naked in the studio. This would be weirdly appropriate, given that itâs a song about getting loaded and acting a fool.Â

14. Santana featuring Rob Thomas // âSmoothâ

When Rob Thomas sang, âMan, itâs a hot one,â the famous opening line of this Latin-rock earworm, he might as well have been talking about this song itself. âSmoothâ spent 12 weeks atop the Billboard Hot 100, reignited the career of Carlos Santana, and dominated radio in the closing months of the second millennium. Itâs hard to imagine anyone but Thomas singing it, but he actually co-wrote it with George Michael in mind.

15. Limp Bizkit // âNookieâ

On the strength of this brutish kissoffâperhaps the most famous song of the nu-metal eraâLimp Bizkitâs 1999 sophomore album, Significant Other, reached No. 1 on the Billboard 200. Itâs among the tunes the band played during their infamous Woodstock â99 set.

16. Macy Gray // âI Tryâ

Macy Grayâs one and only pop hit, the deceptively perky soul-pop heartbreaker âI Try,â almost didnât reach the mass audiences it deserved. Gray fought with her label over the song, insisting it shouldnât be a single. Thank goodness she lost that fight.

17. Destinyâs Child // âSay My Nameâ

Saying the names of the members of Destinyâs Child was a little tricky circa âSay My Name,â the groupâs second No. 1 hit. Though the song includes vocals from BeyoncÃ©, Kelly Rowland, LeTavia Roberson, and LeToya Luckett, the music video features Bey, Rowland, and the two singers who replaced Roberson and Luckett: Michelle Williams and Farrah Franklin. Roberson and Luckett claimed they didnât know theyâd been fired until they saw the video.

18. Christina Aguilera // âGenie In a Bottleâ

The teen-pop era reached its peak in 1999, and Christina Aguilera notched a No. 1 hit with this suggestive lead single from her self-titled debut album. But Aguilera wasnât interested in being a typical pop starâshe fought to infuse her songs with more R&B flavorâand with subsequent LPs, she inserted more of her own personality into the mix.Â

19. LFO // âSummer Girlsâ

Part nostalgic love song, part barrage of unrelated pop culture references, âSummer Girlsâ is a strangely sweet pop-rap confection that somehow never loses its charm. Sadly, LFO frontman Rich Cronin died of leukemia in 2010, followed by bandmate Devin Lima in 2018 and Brian Gillis in 2023.

20. Lou Bega // âMambo No. 5 (A Little Bit Ofâ¦)â

Though tangentially related to both the â90s swing revival and the Latin-pop boom, âMambo No. 5â was very much its own thing. German-born singer Lou Bega based the retro-leaning smash (his lone American hit) on a sample from Cuban bandleader PÃ©rez Pradoâs 1949 chestnut âMambo No. 5.â Begaâs big contribution was adding lyricsâmost notably a hyper-catchy chorus that calls out nine different women: Pamela, Angela, Monica, Erica, Rita, Tina, Sandra, Mary, and Jessica.

21. Olâ Dirty Bastard // âGot Your Moneyâ

Produced by Pharrell and Chad Hugo, a.k.a. the Neptunes, âGot Your Moneyâ became Wu-Tang Clan eccentric Olâ Dirty Bastardâs first and only Top 40 pop hit as a lead artist. ODB gets some help on the hook from singer Kelis, later of âMilkshakeâ fame, who assures him that, yes, sheâs got his moneyâno need to worry.

22. Len // âSteal My Sunshineâ

Perfectly engineered for summer parties, âSteal My Sunshineâ was born early one morning while Len frontman Marc Costanzo was partying at a rave in his hometown of Toronto. He wrote the lyrics on his leg and on a napkin, and if youâre of a certain age, you probably know these words by heart.

23. Dr. Dre // âStill D.R.E.â

Dr. Dreâs big 1999 comeback single features lyrics ghostwritten by none other than Jay-Z. According to Dre, it took Jay a few minutes to get into the West Coast mindset, but once he did, the Brooklyn legend wrote the whole songâincluding guest Snoop Doggâs partsâin 20 minutes.

24. Backstreet Boys // âI Want It That Wayâ

Swedish pop songsmith Max Martin has a questionable command of the English languageâhence the head-scratching lyrics of this 1999 boy-band classicâbut thereâs no doubting his way with a melody. Teen pop arguably never got better than this.

25. Sugar Ray // âEvery Morningâ

Sugar Ray gave the world a handful of perfect pop singles, and âEvery Morningâ might be the best of the bunch. Mark McGrath and the gang based part of the chorus on the Latin-rock band Maloâs 1972 tune âSuavecito,â a staple of lowrider car shows in Sugar Rayâs native Southern California.
